title: Case Study Demo
text: vignette reproduces analysis workflow described BioThermR manuscript. demonstrates process, visualize, analyze thermal imaging data mouse cold exposure experiment (Normal Diet “ND” vs. Cold Exposed “ND4”).

title: Case Study Demo
text: complete dataset used case study (30 raw thermal images) exclusively hosted GitHub version package due size constraints. installed BioThermR CRAN, might miss files. fully reproduce results , please ensure installed full package GitHub:
code: # Install the full version with data from GitHub if (!require("devtools")) install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("RightSZ/BioThermR")

title: Case Study Demo
text: First, ensure dependencies installed. Load necessary libraries.
code: # Install dependencies if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))   install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install("EBImage") library(ggplot2) library(ggpubr) library(BioThermR)

title: Case Study Demo
code: # 1. Get the path to the 30 images included with the package data_folder <- system.file("extdata", package = "BioThermR")  # 2. Read using the batch reading function obj_list <- read_thermal_batch(data_folder) length(obj_list) #> [1] 30  # 3. Use the lapply function to batch call roi_segment_ebimage for segmentation # Otsu's method is used by default obj_list <- lapply(obj_list, roi_segment_ebimage)

title: Case Study Demo
text: Visualize entire dataset
code: # Display the thermal heatmap of one BioThermR object p1 <- plot_thermal_heatmap(obj_list[[1]], use_processed = FALSE) p1 # Display the segmented image of one BioThermR object p2 <- plot_thermal_heatmap(obj_list[[1]], use_processed = TRUE) p2 # Display the 3d image of one segmented BioThermR object plot_thermal_3d(obj_list[[1]]) # Display the ROI density plot of one BioThermR object p3 <- plot_thermal_density(obj_list[[1]]) p3 # Display the overall display montage plot p4 <- plot_thermal_montage(obj_list, ncol = 5, padding = 2, text_size = 3) p4 # Display the overall display cloud plot p5 <- plot_thermal_cloud(obj_list)  p5 ggpubr::ggarrange(p1,p2,p3,p4,p5,labels = c("A","B","C","D","E"))

title: Case Study Demo
text: Extract temperature metrics images merge clinical grouping data.
code: # Batch calculate statistics for each BioThermR object obj_list <- lapply(obj_list, analyze_thermal_stats)  # Compile statistics into a data frame df <- compile_batch_stats(obj_list)  # Read grouping data and merge pd_path <- system.file("extdata", "group.csv", package = "BioThermR") pd <- read.csv(pd_path) df <- merge_clinical_data(df,pd)  # Aggregate technical replicates (e.g., 3 photos per mouse) df_new <- aggregate_replicates(df,                                method = "mean", # use mean method                                id_col = "Sample", # merge by sample                                keep_cols = c("Group")                                ) head(df_new) #>   Sample Group n_replicates      Min      Max     Mean   Median       SD #> 1   ND_1    ND            3 29.36788 35.87173 31.70707 31.55465 1.311257 #> 2   ND_2    ND            3 29.19874 35.92883 32.68671 31.84397 1.970498 #> 3   ND_3    ND            3 28.18887 36.03918 31.75590 31.25142 1.650999 #> 4   ND_4    ND            3 30.37368 35.99798 33.32450 32.42096 1.981652 #> 5   ND_5    ND            3 30.59082 35.99695 33.13636 32.18157 1.982310 #> 6  ND4_1   ND4            3 29.27191 35.91896 32.84147 32.21257 1.994384 #>        Q25      Q75       IQR         CV Peak_Density Rep #> 1 31.07301 31.86817 0.7951624 0.04135084     31.62128   2 #> 2 31.29252 34.58603 3.2935144 0.06027172     31.48556   2 #> 3 30.87554 31.98214 1.1066006 0.05197942     31.09829   2 #> 4 31.73361 35.63418 3.9005693 0.05946340     33.24354   2 #> 5 31.48953 35.62859 4.1390597 0.05982208     31.63697   2 #> 6 31.38211 35.57433 4.1922170 0.06072339     32.02256   2

title: Case Study Demo
text: Finally, compare thermal metrics ND ND4 groups.
code: # Display grouping data plots, grouped by Group my_comparisons <- list( c("ND4", "ND")) # Mean s1 <- viz_thermal_boxplot(data = df_new,                           y_var = "Mean",                           x_var = "Group") +   ggpubr::stat_compare_means(comparisons = my_comparisons,                              method = "t.test",                              label = "p.signif",                              hide.ns = FALSE                              )  # Median s2 <- viz_thermal_boxplot(data = df_new,                           y_var = "Median",                           x_var = "Group")+   ggpubr::stat_compare_means(comparisons = my_comparisons,                              method = "t.test",                              label = "p.signif",                              hide.ns = FALSE   )  # IQR s3 <- viz_thermal_boxplot(data = df_new,                           y_var = "IQR",                           x_var = "Group")+   ggpubr::stat_compare_means(comparisons = my_comparisons,                              method = "t.test",                              label = "p.signif",                              hide.ns = FALSE   ) # Peak Density s4 <- viz_thermal_boxplot(data = df_new,                           y_var = "Peak_Density",                           x_var = "Group")+   ggpubr::stat_compare_means(comparisons = my_comparisons,                              method = "t.test",                              label = "p.signif",                              hide.ns = FALSE   ) ggarrange(s1,s2,s3,s4,ncol = 4,labels = c("A","B","C","D"))

title: Quickstart
text: BioThermR includes example data help get started quickly. load sample .raw thermal file provided package.
code: # 1. Locate the example file provided with BioThermR raw_path <- system.file("extdata", "C05.raw", package = "BioThermR")  # 2. Read the thermal data using read_thermal_raw obj <- read_thermal_raw(raw_path)   # 3. Quick sanity check # This confirms the data is loaded and has the correct dimensions print(paste("Filename:", obj$meta$filename)) #> [1] "Filename: C05.raw" print(paste("Dimensions:", obj$meta$dims[1], "x", obj$meta$dims[2])) #> [1] "Dimensions: 120 x 160"

title: Quickstart
text: Let’s look raw image. Notice background around 28°C (purple/black) subject >32°C (yellow/red).
code: plot_thermal_heatmap(obj, use_processed = FALSE) +    ggtitle("Raw Thermal Image")

title: Quickstart
text: Instead manually guessing temperature threshold, BioThermR can automatically separate subject background using Otsu’s method morphological operations. particularly useful batch processing lighting background temperatures might vary slightly.
code: # Apply automated segmentation # method = "otsu": Automatically calculates the best threshold # keep_largest = TRUE: Removes small noise artifacts, keeping only the animal obj <- roi_segment_ebimage(obj, method = "otsu", keep_largest = TRUE) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 401 pixels )  # Visualize the result (Processed Data) # Note how the background is now clean (NA) plot_thermal_heatmap(obj, use_processed = TRUE) +    ggtitle("Auto-Segmented Image")

title: Quickstart
text: Now background gone (set NA), can calculate accurate body temperature metrics.
code: # Compute Min, Max, Mean, Median, etc. obj <- analyze_thermal_stats(obj)  # Show the results print(obj$stats) #>          Metric       Value #> 1           Min 29.10121918 #> 2           Max 35.88959503 #> 3          Mean 31.59486416 #> 4        Median 31.46377563 #> 5            SD  1.28356576 #> 6           Q25 31.00030899 #> 7           Q75 31.72277069 #> 8           IQR  0.72246170 #> 9            CV  0.04062577 #> 10 Peak_Density 31.52773844

title: Quickstart
text: BioThermR shines processing large datasets. package includes 30 sample raw images extdata folder. load, segment, visualize lines code.
code: # 1. Get the path to the folder containing the 30 raw files data_folder <- system.file("extdata", package = "BioThermR")  print(paste("Reading batch from:", data_folder)) #> [1] "Reading batch from: /private/var/folders/_b/gx4lc14d5ssf7pl9qlkl32r80000gn/T/RtmpoUCExo/temp_libpathc9751db50ac6/BioThermR/extdata"  # 2. Read the entire batch # Note: We use pattern = ".raw" to ensure we only load the raw thermal files batch_list <- read_thermal_batch(data_folder, pattern = "\\.raw$") #> Reading 30 files... #> Batch read completed. Imported 30 files.  # 3. Batch Segmentation (Automated) # We use lapply to apply the 'roi_segment_ebimage' function to every image in the list # This automatically removes the background for all 30 mice batch_list_clean <- lapply(batch_list, roi_segment_ebimage) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 401 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 388 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 419 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 342 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 356 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 327 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 390 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 455 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 409 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 330 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 325 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 320 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 388 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 419 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 414 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 366 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 353 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 347 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 399 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 407 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 382 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 298 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 349 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 362 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 412 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 393 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 371 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 387 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 362 pixels ) #> Auto-Segmentation: Kept largest object ( 389 pixels )  # 4. Visualization A: Gap-Free Montage p1 <- plot_thermal_montage(batch_list_clean, ncol = 5, padding = 2, text_size = 3) +    ggtitle("Montage View: 30 Mice") #> Scanning objects for bounding box dimensions... #> Montage Layout: 6 x 5 | Cell Size: 41 x 37 print(p1) # 5. Visualization B: Thermal Cloud p2 <- plot_thermal_cloud(batch_list_clean, spread_factor = 1.5, jitter_factor = 0.5, show_labels = TRUE) +    ggtitle("Thermal Cloud: Population Overview") #> Processing objects... #> Generating layout for 30 objects... print(p2)

title: Quickstart
text: Finally, extract temperature metrics (Mean, Max, Min, etc.) 30 segmented images compile single table. data frame ready statistical analysis (ANOVA, t-test) export CSV.

title: Authors and Citation
text: BeiHao Li. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Li B (2026). BioThermR: Standardized Processing Analysis Thermal Imaging Data Animal Studies. R package version 0.1.0, https://rightsz.github.io/BioThermR/, https://github.com/RightSZ/BioThermR.
code: @Manual{,   title = {BioThermR: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies},   author = {BeiHao Li},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.0, https://rightsz.github.io/BioThermR/},   url = {https://github.com/RightSZ/BioThermR}, }

what: BioThermR: an R package for standardized processing, visualization, and statistical analysis of thermal imaging data in animal studies
title: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies
text: BioThermR R package designed provide end--end analysis pipeline infrared thermography (IRT) data animal experimentation. addresses lack standardized, reproducible, batch-processing workflows current thermal imaging analysis. Find https://github.com/RightSZ/BioThermR

title: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies
text: BioThermR relies EBImage Bioconductor image processing. Please install first: Install latest development version GitHub follow: CRAN availability Submission CRAN currently progress. package available CRAN upon acceptance.
code: if (!require("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("BiocManager")  BiocManager::install("EBImage") if (!require("devtools", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("RightSZ/BioThermR")

title: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies

what: BioThermR: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies — BioThermR-package
title: BioThermR: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies — BioThermR-package
text: comprehensive framework standardized analysis thermal imaging data animal experimentation. integrates data import (FLIR, raw, CSV), automated interactive Region Interest (ROI) segmentation, high-throughput batch processing. comprehensive framework standardized analysis thermal imaging data animal experimentation. integrates data import (FLIR, raw, CSV), automated interactive Region Interest (ROI) segmentation, high-throughput batch processing.

title: BioThermR: Standardized Processing and Analysis of Thermal Imaging Data in Animal Studies — BioThermR-package
text: Maintainer: BeiHao Li szright2000@gmail.com

what: Aggregate Technical Replicates for Statistical Rigor — aggregate_replicates
title: Aggregate Technical Replicates for Statistical Rigor — aggregate_replicates
text: Collapses technical replicates (e.g., multiple thermal images taken animal)              single biological data point per subject. step crucial avoiding              pseudoreplication downstream statistical analyses (e.g., t-tests, ANOVA).

title: Aggregate Technical Replicates for Statistical Rigor — aggregate_replicates
code: aggregate_replicates(data, id_col, method = "mean", keep_cols = NULL)

title: Aggregate Technical Replicates for Statistical Rigor — aggregate_replicates
text: data data frame. Typically output compile_batch_stats merge_clinical_data. id_col String. column name representing unique Biological Subject ID (e.g., "MouseID", "Subject_No"). Rows sharing ID condensed one. method String. mathematical function used aggregation: either "mean" (default) "median". Median often robust outliers (e.g., one blurry image). keep_cols Vector strings. Names non-numeric metadata columns preserve final output (e.g., "Group", "Genotype", "Sex", "Treatment").

title: Aggregate Technical Replicates for Statistical Rigor — aggregate_replicates
text: data frame exactly one row per unique ID. column order reorganized place         ID metadata first, followed aggregated thermal statistics n_replicates count.

title: Aggregate Technical Replicates for Statistical Rigor — aggregate_replicates
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ df <- aggregate_replicates(   data = df_raw,   id_col = "SampleID",   method = "median",   keep_cols = c("Group", "Sex") ) } # }

title: Calculate Comprehensive Thermal Statistics — analyze_thermal_stats
text: Computes detailed set summary statistics thermal matrix.              Metrics include central tendency (Mean, Median, Peak Density), dispersion (SD, IQR, CV),              range (Min, Max, Quantiles). NA values (background) automatically excluded.

title: Calculate Comprehensive Thermal Statistics — analyze_thermal_stats
code: analyze_thermal_stats(img_obj, use_processed = TRUE)

title: Calculate Comprehensive Thermal Statistics — analyze_thermal_stats
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. use_processed Logical. TRUE (default), calculates statistics 'processed' matrix (background likely masked NA). FALSE, uses 'raw' matrix.

title: Calculate Comprehensive Thermal Statistics — analyze_thermal_stats
text: 'BioThermR' object stats slot updated containing data frame results.

title: Calculate Comprehensive Thermal Statistics — analyze_thermal_stats
text: function calculates following metrics: Min/Max: Extremities temperature distribution. Mean/Median: Measures central tendency. SD (Standard Deviation): Absolute measure spread. IQR (Interquartile Range): Robust measure spread (Q75 - Q25). CV (Coefficient Variation): Relative measure spread (SD / Mean), useful assessing thermal heterogeneity. Peak_Density: temperature value corresponding peak kernel density estimate (Mode).

what: Convert BioThermR Object to EBImage Object — as_EBImage
title: Convert BioThermR Object to EBImage Object — as_EBImage
text: Extracts thermal matrix (raw processed) 'BioThermR' object              converts 'EBImage' class object. conversion essential              applying advanced morphological operations (e.g., thresholding, watershed,              labeling) provided 'EBImage' package.

title: Convert BioThermR Object to EBImage Object — as_EBImage
code: as_EBImage(img_obj, use_processed = TRUE, replace_na = 0, normalize = FALSE)

title: Convert BioThermR Object to EBImage Object — as_EBImage
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. use_processed Logical. TRUE (default), uses 'processed' matrix (might already masks applied). FALSE, uses 'raw' temperature matrix. replace_na Numeric. value replace NAs , 'EBImage' support missing values. Default 0 (typically treated background). normalize Logical. TRUE, scales matrix values linearly range [0, 1]. highly recommended visualization standard thresholding algorithms (like Otsu) 'EBImage'. Default FALSE (preserves actual temperature values).

title: Convert BioThermR Object to EBImage Object — as_EBImage
text: Image object (defined 'EBImage' package).

title: Convert BioThermR Object to EBImage Object — as_EBImage
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load data my_obj <- read_thermal_flir("data/mouse.jpg")  # Convert to EBImage format with normalization (for thresholding) eb_norm <- as_EBImage(my_obj, normalize = TRUE)  # Convert preserving temperature values (for calculation) eb_temp <- as_EBImage(my_obj, normalize = FALSE) } # }

what: Compile Batch Statistics into a Tidy Data Frame — compile_batch_stats
title: Compile Batch Statistics into a Tidy Data Frame — compile_batch_stats
text: Iterates list 'BioThermR' objects, extracts pre-calculated statistics              (analyze_thermal_stats), aggregates single summary data frame.              function transforms nested list structure flat, tabular format (Tidy Data)              suitable downstream statistical analysis (ANOVA, t-test) visualization.

title: Compile Batch Statistics into a Tidy Data Frame — compile_batch_stats
code: compile_batch_stats(img_list)

title: Compile Batch Statistics into a Tidy Data Frame — compile_batch_stats
text: img_list list 'BioThermR' objects (typically output batch processing workflow). Note: analyze_thermal_stats must run objects first populate 'stats' slot.

title: Compile Batch Statistics into a Tidy Data Frame — compile_batch_stats
text: data.frame : Rows represent individual images. Columns include 'Filename' metrics computed analyze_thermal_stats                 (e.g., Min, Max, Mean, Median, SD, IQR, CV, Peak_Density).

title: Compile Batch Statistics into a Tidy Data Frame — compile_batch_stats
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # 1. Import and Process batch <- read_thermal_batch("data/") batch <- lapply(batch, analyze_thermal_stats)  # 2. Compile Results df_results <- compile_batch_stats(batch)  # 3. View head(df_results) } # }

what: Import EBImage Object into BioThermR — from_EBImage
title: Import EBImage Object into BioThermR — from_EBImage
text: Converts 'EBImage' class object back 'BioThermR' framework.              function designed integrate results external morphological              operations (e.g., watershed segmentation, filtering) back standard              BioThermR analytical workflow.

title: Import EBImage Object into BioThermR — from_EBImage
code: from_EBImage(   eb_img,   template_obj = NULL,   name = "Imported_EBImage",   mask_zero = FALSE )

title: Import EBImage Object into BioThermR — from_EBImage
text: eb_img Image object ('EBImage' package). template_obj Optional. existing 'BioThermR' object update. Providing ensures original metadata (like filenames original raw data) retained. Default NULL. name String. name assigned new object (used template_obj NULL). Default "Imported_EBImage". mask_zero Logical. TRUE, converts values 0 imported matrix NA. particularly useful importing binary masks 0 represents background, BioThermR uses NA exclude background pixels statistical calculations. Default FALSE.

title: Import EBImage Object into BioThermR — from_EBImage
text: 'BioThermR' object imported matrix stored processed slot.

title: Import EBImage Object into BioThermR — from_EBImage
text: function supports two modes: Update Mode: template_obj provided, input image replaces                  processed matrix template. Metadata (filename, path) preserved.                  Statistics reset NULL data changed. Create Mode: template_obj NULL, new 'BioThermR' object created                  scratch using input matrix. input eb_img 2 dimensions (e.g., color/RGB), first channel          utilized, warning issued.

what: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
title: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
text: Visually compares two segmentation masks (ROIs) overlaying original thermal image.              function primarily used validation purposes: compare automated segmentation              (filled layer) manual ground truth (contour line).              automatically calculates displays Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) title.

title: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
code: plot_roi_overlap(   img_obj1,   img_obj2,   title = NULL,   color = "green",   alpha = 0.5,   line_color = "white",   palette = "inferno" )

title: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
text: img_obj1 'BioThermR' object. Typically Automated/Predicted segmentation. object must contain raw thermal matrix. mask plotted filled area. img_obj2 'BioThermR' object. Typically Manual/Ground Truth segmentation. mask plotted contour outline. Dimensions must match img_obj1. title String. Custom title plot. NULL (default), title shows "ROI overlap (DICE: X.XXX)". color String. Fill color img_obj1 mask. Default "green". alpha Numeric. Transparency level img_obj1 mask (0 1). Default 0.5. line_color String. Line color img_obj2 contour. Default "white". palette String. Color palette background thermal image (passed scale_fill_viridis_c). Default "inferno".

title: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
text: ggplot object showing overlay.

title: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
text: visualization consists three layers: Background: raw thermal image img_obj1. Prediction (img_obj1): processed mask first object, rendered semi-transparent filled raster (default green). Ground Truth (img_obj2): processed mask second object, rendered contour outline (default white). function calculates Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) using formula:          $$DSC = \frac{2 \times |X \cap Y|}{|X| + |Y|}$$          X Y set pixels two masks. DSC 1 indicates perfect overlap.

title: Visualize ROI Overlap and Dice Coefficient — plot_roi_overlap
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # 1. Automated Segmentation auto_obj <- roi_segment_ebimage(my_image)  # 2. Manual Segmentation manual_obj <- roi_filter_interactive(my_image)  # 3. Compare them plot_roi_overlap(img_obj1 = auto_obj,                  img_obj2 = manual_obj,                  color = "blue",                  line_color = "red") } # }

title: Interactive 3D Thermal Surface Plot — plot_thermal_3d
text: Generates rotatable, interactive 3D surface plot using 'plotly' engine.              visualization maps temperature Z-axis, allowing users intuitively              explore thermal topology, gradients, intensity hotspots.

code: plot_thermal_3d(img_obj, use_processed = TRUE)

title: Interactive 3D Thermal Surface Plot — plot_thermal_3d
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. use_processed Logical. TRUE (default), uses 'processed' matrix (background likely NA). FALSE, uses 'raw' sensor data.

title: Interactive 3D Thermal Surface Plot — plot_thermal_3d
text: plotly object (HTML widget).

title: Interactive 3D Thermal Surface Plot — plot_thermal_3d
text: 3D visualization particularly powerful : Quality Control: Quickly identifying noise spikes "cold" artifacts flat heatmaps might hide. Gradient Analysis: Visualizing heat dissipates central source (e.g., tumor inflammation site). Presentation: Creating engaging, interactive figures HTML reports Shiny dashboards. output HTML widget allows zooming, panning, hovering see specific pixel values.

title: Interactive 3D Thermal Surface Plot — plot_thermal_3d
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create an interactive 3D plot p_3d <- plot_thermal_3d(my_obj)  # Display it (opens in Viewer or Browser) p_3d } # }

title: Generate a
text: Arranges collection segmented thermal objects organic, spiral "cloud" formation.              Unlike rigid grid, layout uses golden-angle spiral (phyllotaxis) algorithm cluster              subjects efficiently. particularly effective visualizing diversity thermal              phenotypes large datasets creating artistic figures presentations covers.

title: Generate a
code: plot_thermal_cloud(   img_list,   spread_factor = 1.1,   jitter_factor = 0.5,   palette = "inferno",   text_color = "black",   text_size = 3,   show_labels = TRUE )

title: Generate a
text: img_list list 'BioThermR' objects. best results, pre-processed (e.g., background removed via roi_filter_threshold). spread_factor Numeric. Multiplier distance objects. Values > 1.0 increase spacing (airier cloud), values < 1.0 pack objects tighter. Default 1.1. jitter_factor Numeric. Introduces random noise placement coordinates break perfect symmetry create natural look. Default 0.5. palette String. color palette 'viridis' package. Default "inferno". text_color String. Color filename labels. Default "black". text_size Integer. Font size labels. Default 3. show_labels Logical. TRUE, displays filename object. Default TRUE.

title: Generate a
text: ggplot object white background void theme.

title: Generate a
text: function performs object-centric rendering: Extraction: image, extracts valid foreground pixels (non-NA),                  ignoring original frame dimensions. Re-centering: object mathematically centered (0,0) relative coordinate system. Placement: Objects placed along spiral path defined Golden Angle (~137.5 degrees). spacing randomness spiral can tuned using spread_factor jitter_factor.

title: Generate a
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load data batch <- read_thermal_batch("data/mice")  # Create an artistic thermal cloud p_cloud <- plot_thermal_cloud(batch, spread_factor = 1.5, jitter_factor = 2.0)  # Save for cover art ggsave("thermal_cloud_cover.png", p_cloud, width = 15, height = 15, dpi = 300) } # }

title: Visualize Temperature Distribution (Density Plot) — plot_thermal_density
text: Generates probability density plot temperature values within image.              visualization critical assessing homogeneity subject's temperature              identifying potential artifacts (e.g., bimodal distributions often indicate poor background removal).

title: Visualize Temperature Distribution (Density Plot) — plot_thermal_density
code: plot_thermal_density(   img_obj,   use_processed = TRUE,   show_peak = TRUE,   show_max = TRUE,   show_min = TRUE,   digits = 2,   color = "skyblue",   point_size = 2,   point_color = "red",   point_label_color = "black",   point_label_size = 2 )

title: Visualize Temperature Distribution (Density Plot) — plot_thermal_density
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. use_processed Logical. TRUE (default), uses 'processed' matrix (masked data). FALSE, uses 'raw' matrix. show_peak Logical. TRUE, highlights labels peak density value (Mode). Default TRUE. show_max Logical. TRUE, highlights labels maximum temperature value. Default TRUE. show_min Logical. TRUE, highlights labels minimum temperature value. Default TRUE. digits Integer. Number decimal places round labels . Default 2. color String. Fill color density area curve. Default "skyblue". point_size Numeric. Size points marking Peak/Min/Max. Default 2. point_color String. Color points marking Peak/Min/Max. Default "red". point_label_color String. Color text labels. Default "black". point_label_size Numeric. Size text labels. Default 2.

title: Visualize Temperature Distribution (Density Plot) — plot_thermal_density
text: ggplot object. Layers can added subsequently.

title: Visualize Temperature Distribution (Density Plot) — plot_thermal_density
text: function computes kernel density estimate valid pixels (ignoring NAs).          can optionally annotate key statistical landmarks: Peak: mode distribution (frequent temperature). Max/Min: hottest coldest points ROI. Text labels automatically repelled using 'ggrepel' ensure overlap.

title: Visualize Temperature Distribution (Density Plot) — plot_thermal_density
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic density plot p <- plot_thermal_density(my_obj)  # Customized plot for publication p_custom <- plot_thermal_density(my_obj,                                  color = "grey80",                                  point_color = "blue",                                  show_min = FALSE) # Hide min label } # }

what: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
title: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
text: Generates high-quality raster plot thermal data using 'ggplot2' framework.              function allows quick visualization raw processed matrices              customizable perceptually uniform color scales (viridis).

title: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
code: plot_thermal_heatmap(img_obj, use_processed = TRUE, palette = "inferno")

title: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. use_processed Logical. TRUE (default), plots 'processed' matrix (showing masking effects). FALSE, plots original 'raw' data. palette String. color map option 'viridis' package. Options include: "magma", "inferno", "plasma", "viridis", "cividis". Default "inferno".

title: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
text: ggplot object.

title: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
text: function performs following steps: Converts thermal matrix long-format data frame suitable ggplot. Renders image using geom_raster. Maps temperature color using specified 'viridis' palette. Ensures aspect ratio preserved (coord_fixed) image appear distorted. Sets NA values (masked background) transparent. Since output standard ggplot object, layers can added subsequently (e.g., new titles annotations).

title: Visualize Thermal Matrix as 2D Heatmap — plot_thermal_heatmap
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Standard plot p <- plot_thermal_heatmap(my_obj) print(p)  # Customize plot (e.g., change title) p + ggplot2::ggtitle("Subject A - Cold Exposure") } # }

what: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
title: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
text: Combines list 'BioThermR' objects single, high-resolution grid plot (montage).              Unlike standard faceting, function uses custom integer-coordinate system              center subject within uniform grid cell, ensuring pixel-perfect alignment              without visual artifacts (white gaps) often seen R raster plots.

title: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
code: plot_thermal_montage(   img_list,   ncol = NULL,   padding = 10,   palette = "inferno",   text_color = "black",   text_size = 4 )

title: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
text: img_list list 'BioThermR' objects (e.g., output read_thermal_batch roi_filter_interactive). ncol Integer. number columns grid. NULL (default), automatically calculated based square root number images create roughly square layout. padding Integer. size whitespace gap (pixels) grid cells. Default 10. palette String. color palette use ('viridis' package). Default "inferno". text_color String. Color filename labels. Default "black". text_size Integer. Font size filename labels. Default 4.

title: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
text: ggplot object representing combined montage.

title: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
text: function executes two-pass algorithm: Scan Pass: Iterates objects calculate bounding box dimensions                  largest subject. defines uniform cell size grid. Layout Pass: Calculates integer offsets required center smaller subject                  within master cell. merges pixel data single master data frame. result rendered using geom_tile(width=1, height=1) guarantee continuous, gap-free visualization.

title: Create a Gap-Free Thermal Image Montage — plot_thermal_montage
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load a batch of images batch <- read_thermal_batch("data/cohort_A")  # Create a montage with 4 columns p <- plot_thermal_montage(batch, ncol = 4, padding = 20)  # Save the high-res result ggsave("montage_cohort_A.png", p, width = 12, height = 10, dpi = 300) } # }

what: Read FLIR Radiometric JPG File — read_thermal_flir

code: read_thermal_flir(file_path, exiftoolpath = "installed")

title: Read FLIR Radiometric JPG File — read_thermal_flir
text: list object class "BioThermR" containing: raw calculated temperature matrix degrees Celsius. processed copy raw matrix, intended subsequent ROI filtering masking. meta list containing metadata: filename, fullpath, dims.

title: Read FLIR Radiometric JPG File — read_thermal_flir
text: function relies 'Thermimage' package external tool 'ExifTool'.          automatically extracts calibration constants (Planck R1, B, F, O, R2)          environmental parameters ensure accurate physical temperature conversion.          Please ensure 'ExifTool' installed added system PATH.

title: Read FLIR Radiometric JPG File — read_thermal_flir

Whether rotate image 90 degrees counter-clockwise. Default TRUE (corrects orientation many standard sensor exports).

what: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
title: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
text: Launches Shiny GUI application allows users interactively refine regions interest (ROI)              batch thermal images. Key features include dynamic temperature thresholding              automated "Clean Noise" tool removes artifacts retaining largest connected object (e.g., mouse).

title: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
code: roi_filter_interactive(img_input, start_index = 1, use_processed = TRUE)

title: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
text: img_input single 'BioThermR' object list 'BioThermR' objects (e.g., read_thermal_batch). start_index Integer. index image start viewing. Default 1. Useful resuming work large batch. use_processed Logical. TRUE (default), interactive filter applied already 'processed' matrix (e.g., refining auto-segmented result). FALSE, starts raw data.

title: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
text: modified 'BioThermR' object (list objects). Note: must assign result         function variable (e.g., data <- roi_filter_interactive(data)) save changes.

title: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
text: function opens local web server (Shiny App). workflow follows: Navigate: Use "Prev/Next" buttons browse image batch. Threshold: Adjust slider set min/max temperature range. Real-time feedback shown plot. Denoise: Toggle "Remove Noise" button. applies topological filter (Connected Component Analysis)                  identifies largest contiguous heat source removes smaller isolated islands (e.g., urine spots, reflections). Confirm: Click "Confirm" lock settings current image auto-advance. Export: Click "Finish & Export Data" close app return processed object list R console.

title: Interactive ROI Selector with Denoising (Shiny App) — roi_filter_interactive
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # 1. Load batch my_data <- read_thermal_batch("raw_images/")  # 2. Launch interactive selector starting from the 10th image # The app allows you to manually refine ROIs and remove noise my_data_cleaned <- roi_filter_interactive(my_data, start_index = 10)  # 3. Save the result immediately after closing the app save_biothermr(my_data_cleaned, "data_cleaned.rds") } # }

what: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
title: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
text: Masks thermal image retaining pixels fall within specified              temperature window. Pixels outside range set NA (background).

title: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
code: roi_filter_threshold(img_obj, threshold, use_processed = FALSE)

title: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. threshold Numeric vector length 2, e.g., c(22, 38). Defines inclusive temperature range [min, max] keep. Use Inf open upper bounds (e.g., c(25, Inf) keeps everything 25 degrees Celsius). use_processed Logical. FALSE (default): filter applied raw matrix, discarding previous masks. TRUE: filter applied processed matrix, allowing cumulative masking (e.g., refining Otsu segmentation).

title: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
text: 'BioThermR' object processed matrix updated.

title: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
text: fundamental segmentation method thermal images.          Since animals typically warmer environment, simple low-pass filter          (e.g., keep > 22 degrees Celsius) often sufficient separate subject cage.          Open boundaries can defined using Inf -Inf.

title: Filter Thermal Image by Temperature Thresholds — roi_filter_threshold
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Simple background removal: Keep everything above 24 degrees obj <- roi_filter_threshold(obj, threshold = c(24, Inf))  # Specific physiological window: Keep between 30 and 39 degrees obj <- roi_filter_threshold(obj, threshold = c(30, 39)) } # }

what: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
title: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
text: Performs automated background removal using hybrid pipeline global thresholding              (Otsu's method), morphological operations, connected component analysis.

title: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
code: roi_segment_ebimage(   img_obj,   method = "otsu",   keep_largest = TRUE,   morphology = TRUE )

title: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
text: img_obj 'BioThermR' object. method String. thresholding algorithm. Currently, "otsu" supported. keep_largest Logical. TRUE (default), keeps largest connected object converts clusters background (NA). powerful denoising step animal experiments. morphology Logical. TRUE (default), applies morphological opening closing operations smooth edges reduce noise.

title: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
text: 'BioThermR' object processed matrix masked         (background pixels set NA).

title: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
text: segmentation pipeline consists four steps: Normalization: temperature matrix scaled [0, 1] compatible 'EBImage'. Thresholding: Otsu's method used calculate optimal global threshold                  separates foreground (subject) background based histogram bimodality. Morphology: disc-shaped brush (size=5) used 'Opening' (remove salt noise)                  'Closing' (fill small holes inside subject). Component Filter: keep_largest TRUE, function labels                  connected regions retains largest one (assuming animal largest heat source),                  effectively removing smaller artifacts like bedding noise reflections.

title: Automated ROI Segmentation via EBImage — roi_segment_ebimage
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load raw data obj <- read_thermal_flir("mouse.jpg")  # Apply automated segmentation obj <- roi_segment_ebimage(obj, keep_largest = TRUE) } # }

what: Save BioThermR Data Objects to Disk — save_biothermr
title: Save BioThermR Data Objects to Disk — save_biothermr
text: Serializes saves single 'BioThermR' object list objects compressed              .rds file. ensures components—raw temperature matrices, processed              masks, metadata, calculation stats—preserved accurately.

title: Save BioThermR Data Objects to Disk — save_biothermr
code: save_biothermr(img_input, file_path)

title: Save BioThermR Data Objects to Disk — save_biothermr
text: img_input single 'BioThermR' class object list 'BioThermR' objects (e.g., output read_thermal_batch). file_path String. destination path (e.g., "results/obj.rds"). directory structure exist, created automatically.

title: Save BioThermR Data Objects to Disk — save_biothermr
text: None (invisible NULL). Prints success message console upon completion.

title: Save BioThermR Data Objects to Disk — save_biothermr
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Save a single processed object save_biothermr(mouse_obj, "data/processed/mouse_01.rds") } # }

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Barplots — viz_thermal_barplot
text: Creates high-quality bar plot compare thermal metrics across experimental groups.              visualization includes bars representing mean, customizable error bars (SD SE),              overlaid individual data points show biological variation.

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Barplots — viz_thermal_barplot
code: viz_thermal_barplot(   data,   y_var,   x_var,   fill_var = NULL,   error_bar = "mean_sd",   add_points = TRUE,   point_size = 1.5,   point_alpha = 0.6,   palette = "npg" )

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Barplots — viz_thermal_barplot
text: data Data frame. merged dataset (e.g., output aggregate_replicates). y_var String. name numeric column plot (e.g., "Max_Temp", "Mean_Temp"). x_var String. name categorical column X-axis groupings (e.g., "Treatment", "Genotype"). fill_var String. name variable used fill colors. Default NULL, uses x_var. error_bar String. type error bar display. Options: "mean_sd": Mean +/- Standard Deviation (shows spread data). "mean_se": Mean +/- Standard Error Mean (shows precision mean). add_points Logical. TRUE (default), overlays individual data points using geom_jitter. highly recommended small sample sizes (n < 20) maintain transparency. point_size Numeric. size individual jitter points. Default 1.5. point_alpha Numeric. transparency jitter points (0 = transparent, 1 = opaque). Default 0.6 handle overlapping points. palette String Vector. string: Pre-defined scientific palettes ("npg" Nature Publishing Group, "jco" Journal Clinical Oncology). character vector: custom list hex codes (e.g., c("#FF0000", "#0000FF")).

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Barplots — viz_thermal_barplot
text: ggplot object. Can customized standard ggplot2 functions.

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Barplots — viz_thermal_barplot
text: function designed produce figures immediately suitable scientific manuscripts.          Key features include: Automatic Statistics: Calculates Mean SD/SE internally using stat_summary. Smart Coloring: Supports scientific palettes ("npg", "jco"). number groups exceeds                  palette size, automatically interpolates generate distinct colors. Layout: Uses theme_classic() automatically expands Y-axis limit                  15% ensure error bars significance annotations fit comfortably.

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Barplots — viz_thermal_barplot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Basic plot with NPG colors p <- viz_thermal_barplot(df_bio, y_var = "Max", x_var = "Group")  # Customizing error bars and point style p_se <- viz_thermal_barplot(df_bio,                             y_var = "Mean",                             x_var = "Genotype",                             error_bar = "mean_se",                             point_size = 2.0,                             point_alpha = 0.8) } # }

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Boxplots — viz_thermal_boxplot
text: Creates high-quality box--whisker plot visualize distribution thermal metrics across groups.              function ideal displaying median values, quartiles, range, optionally overlaying              individual data points reveal underlying sample distribution.

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Boxplots — viz_thermal_boxplot
code: viz_thermal_boxplot(   data,   y_var,   x_var,   fill_var = NULL,   add_points = TRUE,   point_size = 1.5,   point_alpha = 0.6,   palette = "npg" )

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Boxplots — viz_thermal_boxplot
text: data Data frame. merged dataset (e.g., output aggregate_replicates). y_var String. name numeric column plot (e.g., "Max", "Mean"). x_var String. name categorical column X-axis groupings. fill_var String. name variable used fill colors. Default NULL, uses x_var. add_points Logical. TRUE (default), overlays individual data points using geom_jitter. Highly recommended show sample size distribution density. point_size Numeric. size individual jitter points. Default 1.5. point_alpha Numeric. transparency jitter points (0 1). Default 0.6. palette String Vector. string: Pre-defined scientific palettes ("npg", "jco"). character vector: custom list hex codes.

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Boxplots — viz_thermal_boxplot
text: ggplot object. Can customized standard ggplot2 functions (e.g., + ylim(20, 40)).

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Boxplots — viz_thermal_boxplot
text: function includes several automated optimizations scientific reporting: Smart Outlier Handling: add_points TRUE, function automatically hides                  standard boxplot outliers (outlier.shape = NA) avoid plotting data point twice                  (outlier, jittered point). Palette Expansion: Like barplot function, automatically interpolates colors number                  experimental groups exceeds palette's limit. Layout: Uses theme_classic() clean, academic look.

title: Generate Publication-Ready Comparative Boxplots — viz_thermal_boxplot
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Standard boxplot with individual points p <- viz_thermal_boxplot(df_bio, y_var = "Mean", x_var = "Treatment") } # }

what: Create a Thermal Image Montage — viz_thermal_montage2
title: Create a Thermal Image Montage — viz_thermal_montage2
text: Combines multiple BioThermR objects single plot (montage/collage).              Images laid grid, filenames labeled image.              Uses 'processed' matrix (NA values transparent).

title: Create a Thermal Image Montage — viz_thermal_montage2
code: viz_thermal_montage2(   img_list,   ncol = NULL,   padding = 10,   palette = "inferno",   text_color = "white",   text_size = 4 )

title: Create a Thermal Image Montage — viz_thermal_montage2
text: img_list list 'BioThermR' objects. ncol Integer. Number columns grid. NULL, tries create roughly square grid. padding Integer. Pixel gap images. Default 10. palette String. Color palette temperature. Default "inferno". text_color String. Color filename labels. Default "white" (good contrast dark backgrounds). text_size Integer. Font size labels. Default 4.

title: Create a Thermal Image Montage — viz_thermal_montage2
text: ggplot object.
